title._content: Life, Death, and Transformation in the Americas

description._content:
Conservation Interns Kate and Ellen prepare objects for the upcoming exhibition opening in January.

Life, Death, and Transformation in the Americas
opens January 18, 2013

Life, Death, and Transformation in the Americas features some one hundred objects from the Arts of the Americas permanent collection that exemplify the concept of transformation as part of religious beliefs and social practices. Themes of life, death, fertility, regeneration, and spiritual transformation are presented by pre-Columbian, historical, and contemporary artworks, including the Museum’s famous Huastec Life-Death Figure (circa 900–1250), and a Kwakwaka’wak Thunderbird Transformation Mask collected in 1908. Other featured objects include examples of Hopi and Zuni Kachina dolls, Aztec and Maya sculptures, pre-Columbian gold ornaments, and masks from throughout the Americas. Many of the objects are visitor favorites, including the world-renowned Paracas Textile from Peru, a tour de force of ancient Andean weaving.
